div.p:
NOTE: this letter is amongst 1883 letters, with the letter [82.01.17] where M informed Wilson that Sonder had died
Melbourne

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end;

div.p:
I have the honor to solicit a interview with the honorable J. M. Grant, the Chief Secretary, as I am anxious to explain to the honorable Gentleman my desire, to acquire for this Government a large collection of dried plants, formed since the last 50 years by a leading botanist of Europe,
i.e. W. Sonder. the collection having been offered to me in preference to any other purchaser, as I have been in communication with the owner since 36 years. The price is fixed at about £850, and about £50 would additionally be required for the transit. This addition to our own collection, which for Australian species is by far the largest anywhere, would render our botanic museum, in reference to dried plants, one of the largest in the world.
See also M to T. Wilson, 17 January 1882, in this edition as 82-01-17a.
